title: Tetrachromacy and Markov Kernels in Perception
topic_summary: Exploring the relationship between sensory receptor count and perceptual dimensionality using Hoffman's polytope framework, revealing an inverse efficiency ratio across species.
target_audience: Researchers and advanced students in perceptual neuroscience, consciousness theory, and comparative sensory ecology.

scenes.title: Introduction to the Problem
scenes.narration_summary: Hook the audience with the paradox of more receptors not always yielding richer perception, introduce Hoffman's formalism.

scenes.title: The Bottleneck Theorem
scenes.narration_summary: Explain how receptor count doesn't directly determine perceptual dimensions due to neural processing limits.

scenes.title: Polytope Compression Ratio
scenes.narration_summary: Introduce the Markov polytope and the efficiency ratio η = JNDs / k(k-1).

scenes.title: Cross-Species Examples
scenes.narration_summary: Compare humans (k=3, high η) vs mantis shrimp (k=12, low η), discuss tetrachromats.

scenes.title: The Inverse Scaling Prediction
scenes.narration_summary: Present the falsifiable prediction of inverse η scaling with k across taxa.

scenes.title: Implications for Consciousness
scenes.narration_summary: Discuss how this tests Hoffman's theory and implications for AI sensory systems.

scenes.title: Recap and Key Takeaways
scenes.narration_summary: Summarize the core insight: more receptors don't automatically mean richer experience without scaled processing.
